Adopting Ordinance
ORDINANCE NO. 95-G-05
ENACTING AS AN ORDINANCE A CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR THE TOWN OF CLARKSVILLE,
INDIANA, REVISING, AMENDING, RESTATING, CODIFYING, AND COMPILING CERTAIN
EXISTING ORDINANCES OF THE TOWN DEALING WITH SUBJECTS EMBRACED IN SAID CODE
   WHEREAS, the current manner of arrangement, classification and indexing of
general ordinances of the Town of Clarksville, including the range of subject
matter included in a prior code of ordinances, has become insufficient to meet
the immediate needs of the Town; and
   WHEREAS, the Acts of the State Legislature of the State of Indiana empower
and authorize the revision, amendment, restatement, codification, and
compilation of any existing ordinance or ordinances and all new ordinances not
heretofore adopted or published, and further empower the incorporation of said
ordinances into one ordinance in book form;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Town Council of the Town of
Clarksville, Indiana, that:
   Section 1. The general ordinances of the Town of Clarksville as herein
revised, amended, restated, codified, and compiled in book form are adopted as
and shall constitute the “Code of Ordinances of the Town of Clarksville,
Indiana.”
   Section 2. This Code as adopted in Section 1 shall consist of the following
initial titles, to-wit:
   Title I      General Provisions;
   Title III   Administration;
   Title V   Public Works;
   Title VII   Traffic Code;
   Title IX   General Regulations;
   Title XI   Business Regulations;
   Title XIII   General Offenses;
   Title XV   Land Usage;
   Table of Special Ordinances;
   Parallel References; and
   Index.
Additional titles and/or sections may be added from time to time as they are
deemed to be made necessary or desirable through future legislation and
subsequent routine supplementation processes.
   Section 3. All ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated in this Code
adopted on or prior to February 13, 1995, with the exception of Ordinance No.
95-ST-01 adopted on 1-9-95, she be deemed repealed from and after the effective
date of this Code; provided that 1) such repeal shall not affect any offense
committed or penalty incurred or any right established prior to the effective
date of said Code, 2) such repeal shall not affect the provisions of ordinances
levying taxes, appropriating money, annexing or detaching territory
establishing franchises or granting special rights to certain persons,
authorizing public improvements, authorizing the issuance of bonds or borrowing
of money, authorizing the purchase or sale of real or personal property,
granting or accepting easements, plat or dedication of land to public use,
naming or vacating or setting the boundaries of streets, alleys, or other
public places, nor to any other ordinance of a temporary or special nature or
pertaining to subjects not contained therein; 3) such repeal shall not be
construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a
subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance.
   Section 4. Any and all ordinances of a general nature adopted after the date
February 13, 1995, pertaining to and/or amending topics treated in this Code or
deemed as a subject matter necessary as an additional topic for this Code, when
passed in a manner as to indicate the intent of the Council to make the same a
part of this Code, shall be deemed incorporated in this Code so that reference
to this Code shall be understood and intended to include such additions, even
prior to the publication of routine supplements to this Code in which these
ordinances are included.
   Section 5. Said Code shall be deemed published and in full force and effect
as of the day of its adoption and approval by the Council of the Town of
Clarksville, and one copy of said Code shall be filed and maintained in the
Office of the Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of Clarksville.
   SO ORDAINED this 10th day of July, 1995, by the following vote of the
Clarksville Town Council:
      AYES       7
      NAYS       0

§ 10.01 TITLE OF CODE.
   This codification of ordinances by and for the municipality of Clarksville
shall be designated as the Code of Clarksville and may be so cited.
§ 10.02 INTERPRETATION.
   Unless otherwise provided herein, or by law or implication required, the
same rules of construction, definition, and application shall govern the
interpretation of this code as those governing the interpretation of state law.
§ 10.03 APPLICATION TO FUTURE ORDINANCES.
   All provisions of Title I compatible with future legislation shall apply to
ordinances hereafter adopted amending or supplementing this code unless
otherwise specifically provided.
§ 10.04 CAPTIONS.
   Headings and captions used in this code other than the title, chapter, and
section numbers are employed for reference purposes only and shall not be
deemed a part of the text of any section.
§ 10.05 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   General rule. Words and phrases shall be taken in their plain, or
ordinary and usual sense. However, technical words and phrases having a
peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be understood according to their
technical import.
   (B)   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CODE, THIS CODE or THIS CODE OF ORDINANCES. This municipal code as modified
by amendment, revision, and adoption of new titles, chapters, or sections.
   COUNTY. Clark County, Indiana.
   MAY. The act referred to is permissive.
   MONTH. A calendar month.
   MUNICIPAL CORPORATION, MUNICIPALITY, or TOWN. The Town of Clarksville,
Indiana.
   OATH. An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be
substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words SWEAR and SWORN shall be
equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED.
   OFFICER, OFFICE, EMPLOYEE, COMMISSION, or DEPARTMENT. An officer, office,
employee, commission, or department of this municipality unless the context
clearly requires otherwise.
   PERSON. Extends to and includes person, persons, firm, corporation,
copartnership, trustee, lessee, or receiver. Whenever used in any clause
prescribing and imposing a penalty, the terms PERSON or WHOEVER as applied to
any unincorporated entity shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as
applied to corporations, the officers, or agents thereof.
   PERSONAL PROPERTY. Every species of property except real property, as herein
described.
   PRECEDING or FOLLOWING. Next before or next after, respectively.
   PROPERTY. Shall include real and personal property.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Any street or highway, sidewalk, park, school yard, or open
space adjacent thereto and any lake or stream.
   QUORUM. A majority of the members of a board, commission, or committee
holding office, unless otherwise specifically provided in this code.
   REAL PROPERTY. Includes lands, tenements, and hereditaments.
   SHALL. The act referred to is mandatory.
   SIDEWALK. Any portion of a street dedication between the curbline and the
adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways.
   SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION. Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
   STATE. The State of Indiana.
   STREET. Shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads,
alleys, viaducts, and all other public highways in the town.
   SUBCHAPTER. A division of a chapter, designated in this code by a heading in
the chapter analysis and a capitalized heading in the body of the chapter,
setting apart a group of sections related by the subject matter of the heading.
Not all chapters have subchapters.
   TENANT OR OCCUPANT. Applied to a building or land, shall include any person
holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such
building or land, either alone or with others.
   WRITTEN. Any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by
printing or otherwise.
   YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed; equivalent to the words
YEAR OF OUR LORD.
§ 10.06 RULES OF INTERPRETATION.
   The construction of all ordinances of this municipality shall be by the
following rules, unless such construction is plainly repugnant to the intent of
the legislative body or of the context of the same ordinance:
   (A)    AND or OR. Either conjunction shall include the other as if written
“and/or,“ if the sense requires it.
   (B)   Acts by assistants. When a statute or ordinance requires an act to be
done which, by law, an agent or deputy as well may do as the principal, such
requisition shall be satisfied by the performance of such act by an authorized
agent or deputy.
   (C)   Gender; singular and plural; tenses. Words denoting the masculine
gender shall be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders; words in the
singular shall include the plural, and words in the plural shall include the
singular; the use of a verb in the present tense shall include the future, if
applicable.
   (D)   General term. A general term following specific enumeration of terms
is not to be limited to the class enumerated unless expressly so limited.
§ 10.07 SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of this code as now or later amended or its application to
any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not affect
other provisions that can be given effect without the invalid provision or
application.
§ 10.08 REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, such
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, recodified, or renumbered unless the subject matter is
changed or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
§ 10.09 REFERENCE TO OFFICES.
   Reference to a public office or officer shall be deemed to apply to any
office, officer, or employee of this municipality exercising the powers,
duties, or functions contemplated in the provision, irrespective of any
transfer of functions or change in the official title of the functionary.
§ 10.10 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
   If a manifest error is discovered, consisting of the misspelling of any
words; the omission of any word or words necessary to express the intention of
the provisions affected; the use of a word or words to which no meaning can be
attached; or the use of a word or words when another word or words was clearly
intended to express such intent, such spelling shall be corrected and such word
or words supplied, omitted, or substituted as will conform with the manifest
intention, and the provisions shall have the same effect as though the correct
words were contained in the text as originally published. No alteration shall
be made or permitted if any question exists regarding the nature or extent of
such error.
§ 10.11 OFFICIAL TIME.
   The official time, as established by applicable state/federal laws, shall be
the official time within this municipality for the transaction of all municipal
business.
§ 10.12 REASONABLE TIME.
   (A)   In all cases where an ordinance requires an act to be done in a
reasonable time or requires reasonable notice to be given, reasonable time or
notice shall be deemed to mean the time which is necessary for a prompt
performance of such act or the giving of such notice.
   (B)   The time within which an act is to be done, as herein provided, shall
be computed by excluding the first day and including the last. If the last day
be Sunday, it shall be excluded.
§ 10.13 ORDINANCES REPEALED.
   This code, from and after its effective date, shall contain all of the
provisions of a general nature pertaining to the subjects herein enumerated and
embraced. All prior ordinances pertaining to the subjects treated by this code
shall be deemed repealed from and after the effective date of this code.
§ 10.14 ORDINANCES UNAFFECTED.
   All ordinances of a temporary or special nature and all other ordinances
pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall remain in full force and
effect unless herein repealed expressly or by necessary implication.
§ 10.15 EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES.
   All ordinances passed by the legislative body requiring publication shall
take effect from and after the due publication thereof, unless otherwise
expressly provided. Ordinances not requiring publication shall take effect from
their passage, unless otherwise expressly provided.
§ 10.16 REPEAL OR MODIFICATION OF ORDINANCE.
   (A)   Whenever any ordinance or part of an ordinance shall be repealed or
modified by a subsequent ordinance, the ordinance or part of an ordinance thus
repealed or modified shall continue in force until the due publication of the
ordinance repealing or modifying it when publication is required to give effect
thereto, unless otherwise expressly provided.
   (B)   No suit, proceedings, right, fine, forfeiture, or penalty instituted,
created, given, secured, or accrued under any ordinance previous to its repeal
shall in anyway be affected, released or discharged, but may be prosecuted,
enjoyed, and recovered as fully as if the ordinance had continued in force
unless it is otherwise expressly provided.
   (C)   When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause, or provision
shall be itself repealed, the repeal shall not be construed to revive the
former ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it is expressly provided.
§ 10.17 ORDINANCES WHICH AMEND OR SUPPLEMENT CODE.
   (A)   If the legislative body shall desire to amend any existing chapter or
section of this code, the chapter or section shall be specifically repealed and
a new chapter or section, containing the desired amendment, substituted in its
place.
   (B)   Any ordinance which is proposed to add to the existing code a new
chapter or section shall indicate, with reference to the arrangement of this
code, the proper number of such chapter or section. In addition to such
indication thereof as may appear in the text of the proposed ordinance, a
caption or title shall be shown in concise form above the ordinance.
§ 10.18 SECTION HISTORIES; STATUTORY REFERENCES.
   (A)   As histories for the code sections, the specific number and passage
date of the original ordinance, and the most recent three amending ordinances,
if any, are listed following the text of the code section. Example: (Ord. 10,
passed 5-13-60; Am. Ord. 15, passed 1-1-70; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-80; Am.
Ord. 25, passed 1-1-85)
   (B)   If a section of this code is derived from the previous code of
ordinances of the city published in 1986 and subsequently amended, the 1986
code section number shall be indicated in the history by “('86 Code, §      ).”
   (C)   Statutory citations.
      (1)   If a statutory cite is included in the history, this indicates that
the text of the section reads substantially the same as the statute.
   Example: IC 36-5-2-2 (Ord. 10, passed 1-17-80; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-85).
      (2)   If a statutory cite is set forth as a “statutory reference”
following the text of the section, this indicates that the reader should refer
to that statute for further information.
Example:
   § 39.01 PUBLIC RECORDS AVAILABLE.
      This municipality shall make available to any person for inspection or
copying all public records, unless otherwise exempted by state law.
   Statutory reference:
      For provisions concerning the inspection of public records, see IC 5-14-
3-1 et seq.
§ 10.98 OFFENSES PUNISHABLE UNDER SEPARATE PROVISIONS.
   In all cases where the same offense may be made punishable, or may be
created by different clauses or sections of the ordinances of the town, the
prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not more than one
recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense.
('86 Code, § 1-12)
§ 10.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this code for
which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon conviction, be
subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed upon each day during which a violation occurs or continues.

§ 30.01 NUMBER OF MEMBERS.
   The legislative body of the town (the Town Council) shall consist of seven
members:
   (A)   The Town Council shall have one member from each of the five districts
established by §
30.02. Each of the members representing a district shall reside in the district
from which he or she is elected and is to be elected only by the voters of that
district.
   (B)   Further, the Town Council shall have two members, who may reside in
any of the five districts of the town, who are at-large members of the
legislative body and who shall be elected by the voters of the entire town.
(Ord. 2022-G-11, passed 7-19-22)
§ 30.02 (RESERVED).
§ 30.03 DISTRICTS.
   (A)   The Town Council specifies that the Districts shall be composed as
follows:
      (1)   The First District shall be composed of all of Precincts 30, 31,
32, and 33; and that part of Precinct 34 from the following:
         (a)   An area bounded by Brown's Station Way on the west, West Lincoln
Drive on the
south, North Taggart Avenue on the east, and West Adams Avenue on the north and
         (b)   An area bounded by North Sherwood Ave on the west, East Carter
Avenue on the north, Eastern Boulevard on the east, and East Brooks Avenue on
the south.
      (2)   The Second District shall be composed of all of Precincts 35 and
36; that part of Precinct 39 bounded by Longfellow Drive on the south, Thames
Drive on the east, Byron Drive along the north, and Whittier Drive along the
west, including 1505, 1507, 1509, 1511, and 1513 Marlowe Drive of the Meadows
at Green Tree Apartments; and that part of Precinct 42 bounded by Applegate
Lane on the west, East Lewis & Clark Parkway on the north, and US 31 on the
east, and the municipal limits to the south.
      (3)   The Third District shall be composed of that part of Precinct 27
south of Brown Station Way that is entirely within the municipal limits; that
part of Precinct 34 bounded by Eastern Boulevard on the east, Bell Avenue (east
and west) on the north, North Taggart Avenue on the west, and Carter Avenue
(east and west) on the south; all of Precincts 37 and 38; and that part of
Precinct 39 bounded by Blackiston Mill Road on the west, Longfellow Drive on
the south, Whittier Drive on the east, including 1501, 1503, 1417, 1415, 1413,
1411, and 1409 Marlowe Drive of the Meadows at Green Tree Apartments, and
Marlowe Drive, Wyckshire Court, and Marlowe Court along the north.
      (4)   The Fourth District shall be composed of that part of Precinct 27
consisting of lots 4 and 5 of the Jenny Wren Court subdivision; that part of
Precinct 39 bounded by Blackiston Mill Road on the west, Parkwood Drive and
Redwood Drive on the north, Birch Drive, Shelly Drive, and Tennyson Drive on
the east, and Marlowe Drive, Wyckshire Court, and Marlowe Court along the
south; all of Precincts 40 and 41; and all of Precinct 42 except a portion
bounded by 1-65 on the east, Progress Way on the south, Deatrick Drive and the
prolongation of Deatrick Drive to the south line of Lapping Park on the west
and following the south and eastern boundary of Lapping Park to the municipal
limit.
      (5)   The Fifth District shall be composed of that part of Silver Creek
Precinct 6 that is within the municipal limits; all of Silver Creek Precincts
C43 and C44; and that part of Precinct 42 bounded by 1-65 on the east, Progress
Way on the south, Deatrick Drive and the prolongation of Deatrick Drive to the
south line of Lapping Park on the west and following the south and eastern
boundary of Lapping Park to the municipal limit.
   (B)   The Town Council specifically finds that Districts One, Two, Three,
Four, and Five are composed of contiguous territory, are reasonably compact,
contain, as nearly as is possible, equal population, do not cross a census
block boundary except when following a precinct boundary line, and that
crossing the precinct boundary lines is necessary in that the districts would
not otherwise contain, as nearly as is possible, equal population.
   (C)   The Clarksville Planning Department shall report the addresses of the
split precincts to the Clark County Election Board following the adoption of
this section.
(Ord. 2022-G-11, passed 7-19-22)
§ 30.04 POSSESSION OF WEAPONS AT COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   During times that the Town Council is in a scheduled, advertised session,
weapons shall be permitted inside the Town Council chambers by persons lawfully
allowed to possess such weapons.
(Ord. 2017-G-2, passed 2-21-17)

PER DIEM AND TRAVEL EXPENSES
§ 31.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   OFFICIAL BUSINESS. Attendance of schools, seminars, workshops, or
conventions of a civic, educational, or governmental nature.
   OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES. Elected officials, full-time employees, appointed
members of boards and commissions of the Town of Clarksville. The term shall
also include the Town Attorney provided that the Town Attorney shall obtain
prior approval of the Council of any planned travel for
which expenses will be charged to the town; and provided further that the
office, department, board or commission incurring the charges has an
appropriation to cover the travel expenses incurred.
(‘86 Code, § 2-91) (Ord. 84-G-04, passed 3-26-84; Am. Ord. 2006-G-01, passed -
-; Am. Ord. 2024-G-10, passed 9-17-24)
§ 31.02 MILEAGE RATE.
   Town officers and employees may be reimbursed for actual miles traveled in
their own motor vehicles on official business of the town at a rate equivalent
to the federal mileage rate in effect at the time of travel; provided that a
properly documented claim is submitted according to the provisions of §
31.04. For purposes of mileage reimbursement, the number of reimbursable miles
shall not include any travel to or from the employee's home and the
governmental office where they work.
(‘86 Code, § 2-92) (Ord. 84-G-04, passed 3-26-84; Am. Ord. 2006-G-01, passed -
-; Am. Ord. 2024-G-10, passed 9-17-24)
§ 31.03 CLAIMS FOR MILEAGE REIMBURSEMENT.
   All claims for reimbursement of mileage shall be submitted to the Town
Council for approval on General Form 101 prescribed by the State Board of
Accounts. The claims shall set forth the odometer readings from point to point,
and shall not include travel to and from the officer's or employee's home and
the governmental office in which he or she works.
('86 Code, § 2-93) (Ord. 84-G-04, passed 3-26-84; Am. Ord. 2006-G-01, passed --
)
§ 31.04 OTHER TRAVEL EXPENSES.
   Town officers and employees may be reimbursed for meals, lodging, parking
fees, and toll fees incurred when traveling 50 miles or more outside the
corporate limits on official business, and may be reimbursed for supplies or
materials required to be purchased in connection with any school, seminar, or
workshop; provided that the maximum amount reimbursable per day for meals shall
be the actual amount of receipts for meals, including delivery fees and/or
gratuities, for the day or a sum of $59 whichever is less; and provided
further, that a properly documented claim is submitted according to the
provisions in §
31.05 for any expenses incurred.
(‘86 Code, § 2-94) (Ord. 84-G-04, passed 3-26-84; Am. Ord. 2006-G-01, passed -
-; Am. Ord. 2024-G-10, passed 9-17-24)
§ 31.05 CLAIMS FOR REIMBURSEMENT OF OTHER TRAVEL EXPENSES.
   Claims for reimbursement of expenses set forth in §
31.04 shall be submitted to the Board for approval on a standard Town Claim
Form 39 as prescribed by the State Board of Accounts. The claim shall be
completely itemized and supported by receipts.
('86 Code, § 2-95) (Ord. 84-G-04, passed 3-26-84; Am. Ord. 2006-G-01, passed --
)

36.112
TOWN MANAGER
§ 31.10 POSITION AND DUTIES.
   (A)   There is created the position of Town Manager who shall be the
administrative head of the town government.
   (B)   The Town Manager shall serve at the will of the Town Council or for a
definite tenure not to exceed the longest remaining term in office of a member
of the Town Council, in which case he may be dismissed only for cause.
   (C)   No member of the Town Council shall serve as the Town Manager.
   (D)   The Manager must execute a bond for the faithful performance of his
duties.
   (E)   The Manager may not issue or execute bonds, notes, or warrants of the
town.
   (F)   The Manager, under the direction of the Town Council is responsible
for the administrative duties of the Town Council and:
      (1)   Shall attend the meetings of the Town Council and recommend actions
he considers advisable;
      (2)   Shall hire town employees according to the pay schedules and
standards fixed by the Town Council by statute;
      (3)   Shall suspend, discharge, remove, or transfer town employees, if
necessary for the welfare of the town;
      (4)   May delegate any of his powers to an employee responsible to him;
      (5)   Shall administer and enforce all ordinances, orders, and
resolutions of the Town Council;
      (6)   Shall see that all statutes that are required to be administered by
the Town Council or a town officer subject to the control of the Town Council
are faithfully administered;
      (7)   Shall prepare budget estimates and submit them to the Town Council
when required;
      (8)   Shall execute contracts on behalf of the town for materials,
supplies, services, or improvements, after the completion of the
appropriations, notice, and competitive bidding required by statute; and
      (9)   May receive service of summons on behalf of the town.
   (G)   The Manager may not serve as a member of Metropolitan Police, Fire,
and Safety Commissioners.
   (H)   The Manager shall serve as the town's Safety Director:
(Ord. 2016-G-6, passed 6-28-16; Am. Ord. 2020-G-01, passed 3-17- 20)
§ 31.11 APPOINTMENT OF DEPARTMENT HEADS.
   (A)   All supervisors, directors and chiefs of the town's Fire Department,
Police Department, Public Works Department, Utilities Department, Planning
Department, Redevelopment Department, Human Resources Department, Building
Department and their assistant department heads appointed at the Town Council
meeting on January 3, 2019 are hereby confirmed subject to the provisions of
this section.
   (B)   The Town Manager is hereby authorized to and shall have the authority
to remove, substitute, and appoint department supervisors, superintendents, and
chiefs and assistant supervisors, superintendents, and chiefs for the Fire
Department (as allowed by law), the Police Department (as allowed by law), the
Public Works Department, the Utilities Department, the Planning Department, the
Building Department, the Redevelopment Department, the Human Resources
Department, the Parks and Recreation Department, and the Communications
Director.
   (C)   Prior to any change in a department head or assistant department head,
the Town Manager shall consult with the Town Council in executive session.
(Ord. 2019-G-10, passed 6-4-19; Am. Ord. 2022-G-01, passed 1-18-22)
CHAPTER 32: TOWN COURT
Section

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 32.01 ESTABLISHED.
   Pursuant to the provisions of IC 33-35 et seq., there is established a Town
Court for the town, to be known as “The Town Court of the Town of Clarksville.”
('86 Code, § 19-1) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72; Am. Ord. 78-3369, passed 8-
14-78)
§ 32.02 FORCE AND EFFECT OF COURT ORDERS.
   All judgments, decrees, orders, and proceedings shall have the same force
and effect as those of the Circuit Court, except that no judgment shall be a
lien on real estate otherwise than as provided by taking a transcript of such
judgment and filing the same in the office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court.
('86 Code, § 19-2) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.03 SEAL.
   There shall be a seal for the court, which shall contain on the face of the
seal the words “Town Court of Clarksville, Indiana” and a description of the
seal, together with an impress thereof, shall be spread on the records of such
court.
('86 Code, § 19-3) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.04 EXPENSES.
   The Judge shall provide, at the expense of the town, all books, dockets,
papers, and printed blanks necessary for the discharge of the duties of the
court.
('86 Code, § 19-4) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.05 CHANGE OF VENUE.
   There shall be no change of venue from the court, but any defendant may
request a change of judge and a special judge may be appointed as provided by
the law in relation to the Circuit Court.
('86 Code, § 19-5) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.06 APPEALS.
   Any party may appeal a judgment of the Town Court to the Superior or Circuit
Court of the county within 30 days from the rendition in the same manner and
effect, subject to the same limitations and conditions as provided by law for
appeals taken for civil and criminal matters from judgments of justices of the
peace.
('86 Code, § 19-7) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.07 FEES AND COSTS.
   The docket fees and other costs in both criminal and civil cases shall be
collected and distributed in the same amounts and in the same manner as
provided by law and as collected and distributed by city courts.
('86 Code, § 19-6) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
TOWN JUDGE
§ 32.20 ELECTION OF JUDGE.
   The Town Judge shall be elected by the legal voters of the town, at the time
and in the same manner as the other town officials are elected. The term shall
be four years, and until a successor is elected and qualified. The term of
office shall begin at noon on January 1 following the election of the Town
Judge.
('86 Code, § 19-21) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.21 OATH; BOND.
   Before entering upon the discharge of office duties, the Town Judge shall
take and subscribe to the same oath of office as judges of the Circuit Court
and execute a bond with a good and sufficient surety payable to the town in the
penal sum as required by IC 33-35-5, conditioned upon the faithful performance
of the duties of office. The bond shall be approved by the Town Council and
filed in the office of the Clerk.
('86 Code, § 19-22) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.22 COURT SESSIONS.
   The Town Judge shall hold such sessions of the Town Court as the business of
the court demands, at a place to be provided and designated by the Town
Council.
('86 Code, § 19-23) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.23 POWERS AND JURISDICTION.
   (A)   The Town Judge shall have and exercise the powers and jurisdiction now
or hereafter conferred upon justices of the peace and judges of city courts as
provided in state law in all cases of crimes and misdemeanors, except as
otherwise provided.
   (B)   The Town Judge shall have exclusive jurisdiction of all violation of
the ordinances of the town.
   (C)   The Judge shall have original and concurrent jurisdiction with the
Circuit Court or Criminal Court in cases of petty larceny and all other
violations of the laws of the state wherein the penalty provided therefor
cannot exceed the penalty provided in §
10.99.
   (D)   If the Town Judge is of the opinion that the punishment which the Town
Judge is authorized to assess is not adequate for the offense, the Judge may
hold the prisoner for appearance before the proper court, allow for bail, or
commit him to jail in default of the bail.
('86 Code, § 19-24) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.24 VACANCY.
   If such office shall be declared vacant by the Town Council, the vacancy
shall be filled by appointment until the next election of town officers. The
appointing authority shall be the President of the Town Council.
('86 Code, § 19-26) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
§ 32.25 COMPENSATION.
   The judge shall receive such compensation as may be prescribed by the Town
Council.
('86 Code, § 19-25) (Ord. 72-3251, passed 1-10-72)
DRUG AND ALCOHOL INFORMATION PROGRAM
§ 32.40 ESTABLISHED.
   There is established an alcohol information program in the town to be
operated by the Town Judge through the auspices of the Town Court. This program
will be available to Town Court defendants in alcohol and drug related causes,
on a voluntary basis. Its purpose is to educate and inform persons on the
medical and legal aspects of the consumption and use of alcohol and/or drugs.
('86 Code, § 19-41) (Ord. 84-G-02, passed 2-27-84)
§ 32.41 CLASSES.
   (A)   Classes will be held each month and will be conducted by an instructor
appointed by the Town Judge.
   (B)   Each participant in the program shall attend a minimum of four hours
of classes.
('86 Code, § 19-43) (Ord. 84-G-02, passed 2-27-84)
§ 32.42 FEE.
   The Clerk-Treasurer shall collect a $50 enrollment fee from each participant
in the program to be deposited in the town's User Fee Fund.
('86 Code, § 19-42) (Ord. 84-G-02, passed 2-27-84; Am. Ord. 91-G-09, passed 11-
25-91)

METROPOLITAN BOARD OF POLICE  AND FIRE COMMISSIONERS
§ 33.01 RE-ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Metropolitan Board of Police and Fire Commissioners is hereby re-
established.
   (B)   The membership of the Board is shall consist of five members.
   (C)   Each Board member must be a resident of the Town of Clarksville.
   (D)   The Town Council shall appoint the members.
   (E)   Not more than three Board members may be members of the same political
party, if members who satisfy this requirement may be found to serve on the
Board.
   (F)   Those serving as members of the current Board are hereby reappointed
to the same terms, which shall expire on January 1 of the third year after
their original appointment to the Board.
   (G)   Terms of members newly appointed pursuant to this ordinance shall
expire January 1 of the third year after his or her appointment.
   (H)   The Town Council may remove a Board member for any cause that Town
Council considers sufficient.
   (I)   The Board shall have any and all duties and powers prescribed by
Indiana Code as currently enacted or as amended over the Town of Clarksville
Police Department and the Town of Clarksville Fire Department.
(Ord. 2021-G-03, passed 2-2-21)
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
§ 33.15 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION.
   (A)   There is hereby created an Economic Development Commission to be known
as the Clarksville Economic Development Commission.
   (B)   The Economic Development Commission shall consist of three members.
      (1)   The Town Council President shall appoint one member of the Economic
Development Commission who shall serve a term of three years.
      (2)   The Town Council shall nominate one member of the Economic
Development Commission who shall serve a term of two years.
      (3)   The Clark County Council shall nominate one member of the Economic
Development Commission who shall serve a term of one year.
   (C)   After the adoption of this subchapter, the Clerk-Treasurer shall
promptly notify the executives and fiscal bodies required to make selections
and nominations pursuant to this subchapter.
   (D)   Those required to make selections and nominations shall do so within
15 days after receiving notice.
   (E)   Each selectee and nominee shall be appointed by the President of the
Clarksville Town Council within ten days after receiving the nomination.
   (F)   At the expiration of the respective terms of each of the original
economic development commissioners, their respective successors shall be
selected and nominated, before the expiration of the term, in the same manner
as the original commissioner, and each succeeding commissioner shall serve for
a term of four years. A commissioner shall hold over after the expiration of
the commissioner’s term until the commissioner’s successor is appointed and has
qualified.
(Ord. 2023-G-03, passed 4-4-23)
PLANNING COMMISSION
§ 33.30 CREATED.
   There is established an advisory plan commission under authority of IC 36-7-
4-207(b).
('86 Code, § 16-16) (Ord. 2006, passed 5-3-48; Am. Ord. No. 59-3060, passed 11-
16-59)
§ 33.31 MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   The membership of the Plan Commission shall be as provided by IC 36-7-
4-207(b), and shall be composed of:
      (1)   Three official members; and
      (2)   Four citizen members.
   (B)   The three official members shall be appointed by the Town Council, and
shall all be persons in the town government. Terms of these members shall
coincide with their terms of office or appointment.
   (C)   The four citizen members, none of whom shall hold an office in the
town government, shall be appointed by the President of the Town Council. Not
more than two of the citizen members shall be of the same political party.
('86 Code, § 16-17) (Ord. 59-3060, passed 11-16-59)
§ 33.32 TERMS.
   Terms shall expire on the first day of January. Each appointment shall be
for a term of four years.
('86 Code, § 16-18) (Ord. 59-3060, passed 11-16-59)
REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
§ 33.45 REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   There is established for the town a Department of Redevelopment controlled
by a board of five members to be known as the town Redevelopment Commission.
('86 Code, § 16-46) (Ord. 89-G-10, passed 8-14-89)
§ 33.46 COMPENSATION FOR REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION.
   Redevelopment Commissioners are not entitled to salaries, but are entitled
to reimbursement for expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their
duties. This section is retroactive to January 1, 1992.
('86 Code, § 16-47) (Ord. 89-G-10, passed 8-14-89; Am. Ord. 92-G-15, passed 11-
9-92)
§ 33.47 REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY.
   (A)   The Redevelopment Authority shall consist of three board members who
shall be appointed by the Town Council President, pursuant to IC 36-7-14.5.
Members of the Redevelopment Authority Board must be residents of the town. No
profit or money of the Redevelopment Authority may inure to the benefit of a
Board Member.
   (B)   The Redevelopment Authority Board may adopt such by-laws and rules as
it deems necessary to carry out its purpose and function.
   (C)   When the Redevelopment Authority Board determines that the
Redevelopment Authority has substantially fulfilled the purpose for which it
was formed, and all obligations incurred have been satisfied or arrangements
have been made to satisfy those obligations, the Board may declare the
Authority dissolved.
(Ord. 92-G-14, passed 10-12-92)
INSURANCE REVIEW COMMITTEE
§ 33.60 INSURANCE REVIEW COMMITTEE.
   There is established an Insurance Review Committee to serve without
compensation, which Insurance Review Committee shall consist of seven members
as follows:
