('86 Code, § 2-187) (Ord. 85-G-10, passed 11-25-85)
MUNICIPAL CENTER REFUELING FUND
§ 36.070 CREATED.
   There is hereby created an internal service fund designated as the Municipal
Center Refueling Station Fund.
(Ord. 99-G-02, passed 5-11-99)
§ 36.071 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   The Municipal Center Refueling Station Fund is the internal service
fund which shall be used to advance amounts invoiced for all fuel which is
delivered to the tanks located at the municipal center's refueling station,
with such advances periodically being reimbursed as authorized in this
subchapter by transfers from the appropriate departments and funds.
   (B)   The Municipal Refueling Station Fund shall be funded by an initial
transfer of funds in the General Fund, and thereafter by periodic transfers of
funds, which transfers shall be charged as applicable to the funds and
appropriations of the various departments who use the refueling station.
   (C)   Payments from the Municipal Center Refueling Station Fund may be made
without appropriation.
   (D)   The Clerk-Treasurer is hereby authorized to make all transfers
authorized by this subchapter into the Municipal Center Station Fund at such
times, in such amounts, and charged to such funds and department appropriations
as deemed necessary and proper by the Clerk-Treasurer, and that these
reimbursements shall be granted pre-approved expenditure status.
   (E)   The department head or authorized employee responsible for accepting
delivery of the fuels to the refueling station tanks shall complete in the
required manner for each delivery an accounts payable voucher for the invoice
(s) presented, with the amount to be paid the vendor charged to the account
number assigned by the Clerk-Treasurer for the Municipal Service Refueling
Station Fund.
   (F)   The department head or employee who is authorized to obtain printouts
of activities at the refueling station shall periodically provide the Clerk-
Treasurer a printout from the refueling station computer in such a timely
manner as to allow the Clerk-Treasurer to make the required periodic transfers
from the proper appropriations of the various departments utilizing the
refueling station in order to cover the amounts advanced on their behalf from
the Municipal Service Refueling Station Fund.
   (G)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to require the implementation of any
additional procedures in connection with the administration of the Municipal
Service Refueling Station Fund as may be deemed necessary to comply with
municipal budgetary accounting requirements.
(Ord. 99-G-02, passed 5-11-99)
SPECIAL NON-REVERTING  EMPLOYEE HEALTH INSURANCE AND WELLNESS FUND
§ 36.090 CREATED.
   There is created a non-reverting fund for the town's partially self-funded
employee health insurance and wellness plan, which fund shall be known as the
Special Non-reverting Employee Health Insurance and Wellness Fund.
('86 Code, § 2-211) (Ord. 91-G-07, passed 10-14-91; Am. Ord. 2009-G-12, passed
10-5-09)
§ 36.091 CONTRIBUTION FROM VARIOUS DEPARTMENT BUDGETS.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer is directed to transfer from the various
department budgets an amount equal to the maximum claim level plus
administrative costs, or the amount that is actuarially sound at a two-year
reserve level, as determined by the agent of record and the Insurance Review
Committee of the town.
   (B)   Upon completion of such transfer, the Town Council further authorizes
the payment of the current claims level plus administrative costs for the
current plan year to be paid to the third party administrator from the special
non-reverting fund established for purposes of administering the plan.
('86 Code, § 2-212) (Ord. 91-G-07, passed 10-14-91; Am. Ord. 2009-G-12, passed
10-5-09)
§ 36.092 ASSESSMENT.
   The Town Council further approves the assessment of $1 per employee per plan
year, to be determined by the Town Council as a contribution from the employees
for the cost of claims and administration of the health insurance and wellness
plan. All monies collected from employees under this section shall be deposited
in the Special Non-reverting Health Insurance and Wellness Fund.
('86 Code, § 2-213) (Ord. 91-G-07, passed 10-14-91; Am. Ord. 2009-G-12, passed
10-5-09)
§ 36.093 WELLNESS BENEFITS.
   The Town Council further authorizes payments from the Special Non-reverting
Health Insurance and Wellness Fund pursuant to any wellness benefits approved
by the Town Council.
(Ord. 2009-G-12, passed 10-5-09)
LAW ENFORCEMENT EXPENDITURES AND CHARGES
§ 36.110 LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT CONTINUING EDUCATION FUND.
   (A)   Established. A local Police Continuing Education Fund is established
to receive any monies claimed by the town Police Department from the local Law
Enforcement Continuing Education Fund.
   (B)   Deposits. The optional deposit of $.125 each into the operating budget
of the Court Clerk and the Clerk-Treasurer of the town from the $3 fee
collected by the Court pursuant to statute on each applicable case is waived,
and the entire $3 fee collected by the Court on each applicable case is to be
deposited into the local Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund.
   (C)   Disbursements. Expenditures from the local Police Continuing Education
Fund may be made for any purpose authorized by statute; however, provided that
a prior appropriation shall have been obtained for any disbursements from the
fund, and a claim submitted and processed as prescribed by law.
('86 Code, § 10-1) (Ord. 87-G-02, passed 3-9-87)
§ 36.111 (RESERVED).
§ 36.112 DRUG BUY FUND.
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of this section is to authorize the Police
Department to establish a program for drug investigations and to authorize the
use of funds for the undercover purchase of drugs (“buy money”) or as payment
to informants, and to establish the method for expenditure of the funds.
   (B)   Drug Buy Fund. The Town Council establishes a Drug Buy Fund as allowed
by IC 36-1-3. The Police Department shall follow the procedures for
expenditures from the established fund as authorized by IC 36-1-8-3 and any
amendments thereto.
   (C)   Appropriations. Appropriations for the Drug Buy Fund shall be made in
the manner provided by Indiana statutes for other appropriations.
   (D)   Documentation. The Chief of Police or a designee shall document all
expenditures made from the aforesaid Drug Buy Fund through procedures
established and known as “Guidelines for Confidential Expenditures,” Appendix
J, of the Indiana Criminal Justice Planning Agency Financial Guide. The Chief
of Police shall monitor all revenues and expenditures of the Drug Buy Fund, and
shall sign all requests for expenditure of funds from the Drug Buy Fund. A
receipt shall be taken for each expenditure made from the fund. The Police
Chief shall periodically file a voucher, with all original receipts totaling
the cash claimed expended being attached to it, so that the fund can be
reimbursed for expenditures from it. Reimbursement must be approved and made in
the same manner as is required for other expenditures of the town.
   (E)   Revenue Sources. The Police Department for the town may fund the Drug
Buy Fund through donations, court-ordered forfeitures to the Department, court-
ordered confiscations to the Department, and other appropriate sources.
   (F)   Investment of Funds. The Clerk-Treasurer may, with the consent of the
Chief of Police, invest any funds in the Drug Buy Fund in a money market
account, certificate of deposit, or other secure investment. Any accrued
interest from the investment of the funds from the Drug Buy Fund paid by any
bank or other financial institution shall be deposited separately into the Drug
Buy Fund and shall become a part of the fund.
   (G)   Initial Amount. The initial amount to be distributed to the Chief of
Police to be used for the purposes of the Police Drug Buy Fund shall be $4,000.
(Ord. 92-G-06, passed 6-29-92; Am. Ord. 92-G-11, passed 8-10-92)
§ 36.113 MOTOR VEHICLE INSPECTION FEES.
   (A)   The Police Department is authorized and directed to collect a fee of
$5 for the inspection process for each motor vehicle which must be inspected
prior to registration in the state.
('86 Code, § 20-86) (Ord. 83-G-03, passed 10-31-83; Am. Ord. 88-G-03, passed 5-
31-88)
   (B)   A receipt shall be issued by the Police Department for each inspection
fee collected. The revenues so collected shall be periodically, not less than
monthly, delivered to the Clerk-Treasurer of the town, and the revenues
received from the inspections authorized by this division shall be deposited
into the vehicle inspection fund, appropriations from which may only be used
for law enforcement purposes.
('86 Code, § 20-87) (Ord. 83-G-03, passed 10-31-83; Am. Ord. 88-G-03, passed 5-
31-88)
§ 36.114 POLICE NON-REVERTING FUND FOR FORFEITED MONIES.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled Clarksville Police
Non-Reverting Fund for Forfeited Monies. The fund is established for the
purpose of receiving, holding and dispersing monies that have been found or
seized by the Police Department and forfeited for its use and for the purpose
of receiving, holding, and dispersing monies that have been ordered by the
courts to be paid to the Police Department as restitution. The Police
Department shall deposit monies that have been seized and forfeited from
criminal defendants into this fund and shall deposit monies that have been
received as a result of a court order that restitution be paid to the Police
Department.
   (B)   Following its annual court-ordered inventory, the Police Department
may use funds from the Clarksville Police Department Non-Reverting Fund for
Forfeited Monies for reasonable and necessary police department expenditures as
allowed by law. Monies from the Clarksville Police Department Non-Reverting
Fund for Forfeited Monies may be dispersed without appropriation in payment
after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (C)   Authorization for the fund shall expire with the Police Department
notifies the Town Council that the purposes of the fund no longer exist or a
subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds remaining in the account shall
be transferred to the General Fund.
(Ord. 2012-G-01, passed 2-6-12)
§ 36.115 POLICE NON-REVERTING FUND FOR GRANT MONIES.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled Clarksville Police
Non-Reverting Fund for Grant Monies. The fund is established for the purpose of
receiving, holding, and dispersing monies received by the Police Department
from state or federal agencies for specific purposes.
   (B)   The Police Department may use funds from the Clarksville Police Non-
Reverting Fund for Grant Monies for any purpose for which the grant money was
received, according to the terms of the granting agency. Monies from the
Clarksville Police Non-Reverting Fund for Grant Monies may be dispersed without
appropriation after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (C)   Authorization for the fund shall expire when the Police Department
notifies the Town Council that the purposes of the fund no longer exist or a
subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds remaining in the account shall
be transferred to the General Fund.
(Ord. 2012-G-08, passed 7-2-12)
§ 36.116 POLICE NON-REVERTING FUND FOR FEDERAL FORFEITED MONIES.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled Clarksville Police
Non-Reverting Fund for Federal Forfeited Monies. The fund is established for
the purpose of receiving, holding and dispersing monies that have been received
by the Police Department from United States law enforcement agencies as a
result of forfeitures made by United States law enforcement activities. The
Police Department shall deposit monies that have been received by it from
United States law enforcement agencies as a result of forfeitures into this
fund.
   (B)   Following an inventory and accounting of this fund, the Clarksville
Police Department may use funds from the Clarksville Police Non-Reverting Fund
for Federal Forfeited Monies for reasonable and necessary police department
expenditures for safety equipment and safety related purposes as allowed by
law. Monies from the Clarksville Police Non-Reverting Fund for Federal
Forfeited Monies may be dispersed without appropriation in payment after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (C)   Authorization for the fund shall expire when the Police Department
notifies the Town Council that the purposes of the fund no longer exist or a
subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds remaining in the account shall
be transferred to the General Fund.
(Ord. 2013-G-01, passed 1-7-13)
§ 36.117 POLICE OVERTIME REIMBURSEMENT NON-REVERTING FUND.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled "Police Overtime
Reimbursement Non-Reverting Fund" for the purpose of receiving, holding and
dispersing money received from the federal government for reimbursement of
overtime costs incurred by the Town of Clarksville for Town of Clarksville
police officers who work on federal law enforcement cases. Hereafter the Clerk-
Treasurer shall not deposit into the General Fund or other funds such
reimbursement money received from the federal government but shall deposit
those funds into said non-reverting fund.
   (B)   The funds to be deposited into the Police Overtime Reimbursement Non-
Reverting Fund shall only include money received from the federal government
for reimbursement of overtime costs incurred by Town of Clarksville police
officers who work on federal law enforcement cases.
   (C)   The funds from the "Police Overtime Reimbursement Non-Reverting Fund"
may only be used to pay for overtime expenses incurred by the Town of
Clarksville for Town of Clarksville police officers who work on federal law
enforcement cases. Monies from the "Police Overtime Reimbursement Non-Reverting
Fund" may be dispersed without appropriation in payment after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim by the Chief of the Clarksville Police
Department; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (D)   Claims under this section may be treated as preapproved claims
pursuant to IC 36-5-4-12.
   (E)   Authorization for the fund shall expire when the Chief of the
Clarksville Police Department notifies the Town Council that the purposes of
the fund no longer exist, or a subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds
remaining in the account shall be transferred to the General Fund.
(Ord. 2024-G-14, passed 10-1-24)
UNSAFE BUILDING FUND
§ 36.130 ESTABLISHMENT OF UNSAFE BUILDING FUND.
   (A)   Purpose and authority.
      (1)   The Town Council has established an Unsafe Building Authority
pursuant to IC 36-7-9-2 to protect the life, public safety, health and general
welfare of the citizens of the town.
      (2)   The town has determined that there is a need to established a non-
reverting fund for this Unsafe Building Authority to be utilized by the Unsafe
Building Authority.
      (3)   Pursuant to IC 36- 7-9-14, the town desires to establish the Unsafe
Building Non-Reverting Fund (the Fund) pursuant to the provisions contained
herein.
   (B)   Establishment.
      (1)   The Unsafe Building Authority Non-Reverting Fund shall be and is
hereby established.
      (2)   The Unsafe Building Enforcement Authority hereby establishes in its
operating budget a fund designated as the Unsafe Building Fund. Any balance
remaining at the end of a fiscal year shall be carried over in the fund for the
following year and does not revert to the General Fund.
   (C)   Money for the Unsafe Building Fund may be received from any source,
including appropriations by local, state, or federal governments, and
donations. The following money shall be deposited in the Fund:
      (1)   Money received as payment for or settlement of obligations or
judgments established under IC 36-7-9 through 36-7-13 and IC 36-7-17 through
36-7-22.
      (2)   Money received from bonds posted under IC 36-7- 9.
      (3)   Money received in satisfaction of receivers’ notes or certificates
that were issued under IC 36-7-9-20 and were purchased with money from the
Unsafe Building Fund.
      (4)   Money received for payment or settlement of civil penalties or
fines imposed under IC 36-7-9-7.
      (5)   Money received from the collection of special assessments under IC
36-7-9-13.
      (6)   Money received from the fee required for registration of foreclosed
properties.
   (D)   Money in the Unsafe Building Fund may be used for the expenses
incurred in carrying out the purposes of IC 36-7-9-7, including:
      (1)   The cost of obtaining reliable information about the identity and
location of each person who owns a substantial property interest in unsafe
premises;
      (2)   The cost of an examination of an unsafe building by a registered
architect or registered engineer not employed by the department;
      (3)   The cost of surveys necessary to determine the location and
dimensions of real property on which an unsafe building is located;
      (4)   The cost of giving notice of orders, notice of statements of
recession, notice of continued hearing, and notice of statements that public
bids are to be let in the manner prescribed by IC 36-7-9-25;
      (5)   The price bid of work by a contractor under IC 36- 7-9-10 or IC 36-
7-9-12 through 36-7-9-22;
      (6)   The cost of emergency action under IC 36-7-9- 9; and
      (7)   The cost of notes or receivers’ certificates issued under IC 36-7-
9-20.
   (E)   Payments or uses of the Fund shall be made through claim procedure,
without necessity of appropriation by the Town Council in accordance with
applicable law.
(‘86 Code, § 4-184) (Ord. 86-G-05, passed 5-27-86; Am. Ord. 2012-G-06, passed
6-4-12)
PAYMENT WARRANTS
§ 36.140 TYPES OF EXPENSES.
   The Clerk-Treasurer is granted the authority to issue warrants in payment of
the following types of expenses for both the town and the town's wastewater
treatment utility without the prior approval of the Town Council or other
boards or commissions having authority to approve such claims.
   (A)   Necessary transfers of funds to the Payroll Fund or the Insurance Fund
of the town;
   (B)   Transfers of funds between depositories or bank accounts of the town;
   (C)   Payroll claims, including the distribution of payroll withholdings;
   (D)   Claims for utilities, including claims to vendors providing long-
distance services and mobile or cellular phone services;
   (E)   Claims for the employer's share of employee group insurance premiums
or obligations such as administrative fees authorized under the policy
agreement;
   (F)   Employer's share of employee retirement plans;
   (G)   Employer's share of FICA and Medicare;
   (H)   Claims for reimbursable unemployment benefits and charges;
   (I)   Claims for temporary loans either from fund to fund within the town
funds or between the wastewater treatment utility and the town, and claims for
the repayment of such loans;
   (J)   Claims for the purchase of investments;
   (K)   Claims for the payment of leases or lease-purchase agreements
previously entered into by the Town Council or the Parks and Recreation Board,
or an agent or other official at the direction or on behalf of the Town Council
or the Parks and Recreation Board;
   (L)   Claims for the payment of principal and interest on bond issues;
   (M)   Claims for the payment of principal and interest on loans or notes
previously approved by the Town Council or the Parks and Recreation Board or an
agent or other official at the direction or on behalf of the Town Council or
the Parks and Recreation Board;
   (N)   Claims for payments made pursuant to the terms of contracts or
franchise agreements which have been approved and executed previously by the
Town Council or the Parks and Recreation Board, or the town's Redevelopment
Commission, or by any other agent or official at the direction and on behalf of
the Town Council or Parks and Recreation Board.
   (O)   Claims for refunds of amounts received for fees or billings which are
determined to be due the payees, including but not limited to refunds due from
the discontinuation of wastewater treatment services;
   (P)   Claims for seminars, roundtables, workshops, or other similar events
which require a registration fee in advance of the event;
   (Q)   Claims for postage;
   (R)   Claims for buy money from the Buy Money Fund;
   (S)   General grant programs where advance refunding is not prohibited and
the contracting party posts sufficient security to cover the amount advanced;
   (T)   Grants of state funds;
   (U)   Maintenance or service agreements;
   (V)   Payments on state or federal tax returns, including but not limited to
special fuel taxes, sales and use taxes, and state gross income taxes;
   (W)   Payment of insurance premiums on town property, including but not
limited to general liability insurance policies, automobile insurance policies,
and boiler and machinery policies;
   (X)   Payment of premiums for Workmen's Compensation coverage.
   (Y)   Property or services purchased or leased from the United States
government or an agency or political subdivision of the United States
government. The services in this section shall be deemed to include, but not be
limited to, charges for license and permit fees, filing fees, recording fees,
and fees for the release of liens filed by the town that have been recorded in
connection with authorized activities of the town, including delinquent sewer
charges or abandoned building costs.
   (Z)   Expenses that must be paid because of emergency circumstances.
   (AA)   Expenses to be paid from the town's Donation Fund, with monies that
have been donated for a specific purpose or project.
   (BB)   Credit card, charge card, and other charge accounts of the town.
   (CC)   Tolling expenses for the Ohio River bridges incurred for town
business.
(Ord. 93-G-01, passed 1-11-93: Am. Ord. 2001-G-03, passed 5-29-01; Am. Ord.
2017-G-04, passed 3-21-17)
§ 36.141 PURCHASES OR SERVICES.
   Claims for any purchase or service approved by motion of the Town Council or
the Parks and Recreation Board at any regular or special meeting but which do
not appear on the register of claims presented at that meeting may be paid as a
pre-approved claim and reflected on a subsequent register of claims presented
to the approving body.
(Ord. 93-G-01, passed 1-11-93)
§ 36.142 REVIEW BY COUNCIL.
   Any such pre-approved payments must still be supported by a fully itemized
claim and shall be reviewed and allowed at the next subsequent regular or
special meeting following pre-approved payment of the expense.
(Ord. 93-G-01, passed 1-11-93)
PURCHASING RULES AND POLICIES
§ 36.150 INVITATION FOR BIDS.
   (A)   All notices of invitation for bids shall be published in accordance
with IC 5-3-1 in the Jeffersonville Evening News and posted at the Clarksville
Municipal Center Administration Building.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall schedule the publication of notice to
provide a reasonable amount of time for preparation and submission of bids. The
notice will be published two times, at least one week apart. The second
publication must occur at least ten days prior to the date the bids will be
opened.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.151 REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS.
   (A)   All requests for proposals shall be published in accordance with IC 5-
3-1 in the Jeffersonville Evening News and posted at the Clarksville Municipal
Center Administration Building.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall schedule the publication of notice to
provide a reasonable amount of time for preparation and submission of
proposals. The notice will be published two times, at least one week apart. The
second publication must occur at least ten days prior to the date the bids will
be opened.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.152 REQUEST FOR SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   All notices of request for specifications shall be published in
accordance with IC 5-3-1 in the Jeffersonville Evening News and posted at the
Clarksville Municipal Center Administration Building.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall schedule the publication of notice to
provide a reasonable amount of time for preparation and submission of
proposals. The notice will be published two times, at least one week apart. The
second publication must occur at least ten days prior to the date the bids will
be opened.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.153 ELECTRONIC NOTICES.
   Whenever a notice or other material, including specifications, invitation
for bids, request for proposal, is sent, by mail, the purchasing agent may also
send the notice or other material by electronic means provided that the
transmission of the information is at least as efficient as mailing the
information.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.154 OPENING BIDS.
   (A)   Bids received in response to an invitation for bids must be opened
publicly in the presence of at least one or more witnesses at the time and
place designated in the invitation for bids.
   (B)   Proposals received in response to a request for proposals must be
opened so as to avoid disclosure of the contents to competing offerors during
the process of negotiation.
   (C)   Proposals received in response to a request for specifications may be
opened as specified in the request for specifications.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.155 ELECTRIC RECEIPT OF OFFERS.
   (A)   The purchasing agency may receive electronic offers in response to an
invitation to bid, request for proposals or request for specifications.
   (B)   An electronic offer may only be deemed received if:
      (1)   The solicitation includes the procedure for the electronic
transmission of the offer; and
      (2)   The purchasing agency receives the offeror on a fax machine or
other system with a security feature that protects the contents of the
electronic offer with the same degree of protection as provided an offer not
transmitted electronically.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.156 CORRECTION AND WITHDRAWAL OF BIDS.
   (A)   An offeror may correct inadvertent errors in a bid up to the time at
which bids will be opened by supplementing the erroneous bid and submitting a
revised bid.
   (B)   A bidder may withdraw a bid containing inadvertent errors up to the
time at which bids will be opened and for a period of not more than 24 hours
after the time at which the bids were opened.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.157 CANCELLATION OF SOLICITATION.
   When the purchasing agent makes a written determination that it is in the
town's best interests, the purchasing agent may cancel a solicitation or reject
all offers, provided that the solicitation included information concerning the
procedure for cancellation.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.158 SMALL PURCHASES.
   The purchasing agent may purchase supplies with an estimated cost not to
exceed $5,000 on the open market without inviting or receiving quotes.
(Ord. 98-G-06, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.159 PROTECTION OF OFFERS; STATUS OF DOCUMENTS AS PUBLIC RECORDS.
   (A)   Protection of Offers to Opening. The Clerk Treasurer of the Town of
Clarksville, as purchasing agent under the Act, shall retain all offers
received in a secure location prior to the date and time at which offers will
be opened in order to prevent disclosure of the contents prior to the opening
of the offers.
   (B)   Unobstructed Evaluation of Offers. After offers have been opened, the
purchasing agent shall be responsible for maintaining the offers in such a
manner as to permit evaluation of the offers by the persons responsible for
evaluating the offers.
   (C)   Public Records Status of Bids. Bids submitted in response to an
invitation for bids must be made available for public inspection and copying
after the time of the bid opening, unless the bid opening is delayed, as
authorized in this ordinance or other statute or ordinance.
   (D)   Register of Proposals. The purchasing agent shall prepare a register
of proposals for each request for proposals issued which shall contain
information concerning the proposals available for public inspection and
copying. Proposals may not be disclosed.
(Ord. 98-G-03, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.160 DISCUSSIONS WITH OFFERORS RESPONDING TO A REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS.
   The purchasing agent may conduct discussions with, and best and final offers
may be obtained from responsible offerors who submit proposals determined to be
reasonably susceptible of being selected for a contract award.
(Ord. 98-G-03, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.161 DELAY OF OPENINGS OF OFFERS.
   When the Town Council makes a written determination that is in the Town's
best interest, offers may be opened after the time stated in the solicitation.
The date, time, and place of the rescheduled opening must be announced at the
time and place of the originally scheduled opening.
(Ord. 98-G-03, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.162 EVIDENCE OF FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   (A)   Purchases Less Than $25,000. The purchasing agent may not require
evidence of financial responsibility when the estimated cost of a purchase is
less than $25,000.
   (B)   Purchases Between $25,000 and $100,000. The solicitation may include a
requirement that an offeror provide evidence of financial responsibility. If
evidence of financial responsibility is required, the solicitation must
indicate the kind of evidence that will be acceptable. If a bond or certified
check is required, it may not exceed 10% of the estimated cost of the purchase.
   (C)   Purchases Over $100,000. The solicitation shall include a requirement
that an offerer provide evidence of financial responsibility and must indicate
the kind of evidence that will be acceptable. If a bond or certified check is
required, it may not exceed 10% of the estimated cost of the purchase.
   (D)   Small Business Set-Asides. The purchasing agent may determine that no
evidence of financial responsibility shall be required for a small business
set-aside purchase.
(Ord. 98-G-03, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.163 USE OF REQUESTS FOR PROPOSALS (RFP) FOR PURCHASES OF DESIGNATED TYPES
OF SUPPLIES.
   The Clarksville Town Council determines that it is either not practical or
not advantageous to purchase certain types of supplies by sealed competitive
bidding, and receiving proposals is the preferred method for purchasing certain
types of supplies. The Town Council may designate such in writing.
(Ord. 98-G-03, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.164 MODIFICATION AND TERMINATION OF CONTRACTS.
   (A)   Price Adjustments. The Town Council, as purchasing agent, may include
provisions to permit price adjustments in a purchase contract. The following
provisions for price adjustments may be included:
      (1)   Price adjustments must be computed by agreement on a fixed price
adjustment before the beginning of the pertinent performance or as soon after
the beginning of performance as possible;
      (2)   Price adjustments must be computed by unit prices in the contract
or subsequently agreed upon;
      (3)   Price adjustments must be computed by costs attributable to the
events or situations under such clauses with adjustment of profit or fee, all
as specified in the contract or subsequently agreed upon;
      (4)   Price adjustment must be computed in such other manner as the
contracting parties may mutually agree upon; or
      (5)   In the absence of agreements by the parties, price adjustments must
be computed by a unilateral determination of the town of the costs attributable
to the events or situations under such clauses with adjustment of profit or
fee, all as computed by the town of the costs attributable to the events or
situations under such clauses with adjustment of profit or fee, all as computed
by the town in accordance with applicable ordinances adopted by the town.
   (B)   Adjustments in Time of Performance. The purchasing agent may include
provisions in a purchase contract concerning adjustments for time of
performance under the contract.
   (C)   Unilateral Rights of the Town. The purchasing agent may include in a
purchase contract provisions dealing with the unilateral right of the Town, the
purchasing agent, or the president of the Town Council, to order changes in the
work within the scope of the contract or to order temporary work stoppage or
delays in time of performance.
   (D)   Quality Variations. The purchasing agent may include in a purchase
contract provisions dealing with variations between the estimated quantities of
work in a contract and the actual quantity delivered.
(Ord. 98-G-03, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.165 SMALL BUSINESS SET-ASIDE PURCHASES.
   The Town Council hereby establishes criteria for determining qualifications
as a small business and to identify specific supplies for small business set-
aside purchases:
   (A)   Qualification. A business qualifies as a small business if it
qualifies as a small business under the standards established by the Indiana
Department of Commerce.
   (B)   Businesses Not Eligible. The following businesses are not eligible for
the town's small business set-aside:
      (1)   A wholesale business with average annual sales for the most
recently completed fiscal year in excess of $4 Million.
      (2)   A construction business with average annual receipts for the
preceding three fiscal years in excess of $4 Million.
      (3)   A retail business or a business selling services with annual sales
and receipts which exceed $500,000.
      (4)   A manufacturing business which employs more than 100 persons.
   (C)   Specific Supplies Eligible for Small-Business Set Asides. The
purchasing agency may from time to time designate, in writing, specific
supplies which are eligible for small business set-asides.
(Ord. 98-G-04, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.166 INDIANA BUSINESS PREFERENCE.
   Qualification. An offeror is an Indiana business if it is incorporated in
the state or registered as a domestic corporation or limited liability company
with the Indiana Secretary of State, owned by an Indiana resident or residents,
and has its principal place of business and corporate headquarters in the
state.
(Ord. 98-G-04, passed 6-30-98)
§ 36.167 SUPPLIES MANUFACTURED IN THE UNITED STATES.
   Supplies manufactured in the United States shall be specified for all town
purchases and such supplies shall be purchased unless the Town Council
determines that:
   (A)   The supplies required are not manufactured in the United States in
reasonably available quantities;
   (B)   The price of the required supplies manufactured in the United States
exceed the price of available and comparable supplies manufactured elsewhere by
an unreasonable amount;
   (C)   The quality of the needed supplies manufactured in the United States
is substantially less than the quality of comparably priced available supplies
manufactured elsewhere;
   (D)   The purchase of supplies manufactured in the United States is not in
the public interest.
(Ord. 98-G-05, passed 6-30-98)
NON-REVERTING FUND ATLANTIS WATER PARK
§ 36.175 CREATED.
   (A)   A special non-reverting operating fund is established for the purpose
of receiving and holding fees charged by the Parks Department and/or Parks and
Recreation Board in regard to the water park known as Atlantis. This fund shall
be entitled “Clarksville Parks and Recreation Non-Reverting Fund/Atlantis Water
Park” and the moneys may be expended from this fund only upon the filing of a
proper claim in issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer after
appropriation by the Town Council. Hereafter, the Clerk-Treasurer shall not
deposit moneys received by the Parks and Recreation Department as activity fees
from the operation of the water park known as Atlantis into the Parks
Department's General Fund, but shall deposit those funds into said non-
reverting fund.
   (B)   The Park and Recreation Department and the Park and Recreation Board
are hereby required to use the non-reverting fund to the extent and in the
manner allowed by law.
   (C)   The authorization for this non-reverting fund shall expire when the
lease of the property known as the Atlantis Water Park terminates or as a
subsequent ordinance provides, and funds in the account shall be transferred to
the Park and Recreation Department General Fund.
(Ord. 2000-G-02, passed 4-11-00)
§ 36.176 USE OF FUNDS.
   The moneys deposited in the Clarksville Parks and Recreation Non-reverting
Fund/Atlantis Water Park may be used for all reasonable and necessary
expenditures incurred in the management of the leased Atlantis Water Park.
(Ord. 2000-G-02, passed 4-11-00)
NON-REVERTING FUND SENIOR CITIZEN TRIPS
§ 36.180 CREATED.
   (A)   A special non-reverting operating fund is hereby established for the
purpose of receiving and holding fees charged by the Clarksville Parks
Department and or Clarksville Parks and Recreation Board in regard to senior
citizen trips. This fund shall be entitled "Clarksville Parks and Recreation
Non-Reverting Fund/Senior Citizen Trips" and the moneys may be expended from
this fund only upon the filing of a proper claim in issuance of a warrant by
the Clarksville Clerk-Treasurer after appropriation by the Clarksville Town
Council. Hereafter the Clerk-Treasurer shall not deposit moneys received by the
Clarksville Parks art Recreation Department as activity fees from the operation
of the senior citizen trips, adult classes, programs and activities into the
Parks Department's General Fund, but shall deposit those funds into said non-
reverting fund.
   (B)   The Park and Recreation Department and the Park and Recreation Board
are hereby required to use the non-reverting fund to the extent and in the
manner allowed by law.
   (C)   The authorization for this non-reverting fund shall expire when a
subsequent ordinance provides, and funds in the account shall be transferred to
the Park and Recreation Department General Fund.
(Ord. 2000-G-05, passed 9-26-00; Am. Ord. 2014-G-6, passed 12-29-14)
§ 36.181 USE OF FUNDS.
   The moneys deposited in the special non-reverting operating fund may be used
for all reasonable and necessary expenditures incurred in the management of the
senior citizen trips, adult classes, programs, and activities.
(Ord. 2000-G-05, passed 9-26-00; Am. Ord. 2014-G-6, passed 12-29-14)
LOCAL SUPPLEMENTAL ADULT PROBATION SERVICES FUND
§ 36.185 CREATED.
   (A)   A special fund is hereby created and identified as the "Local
Supplemental Adult Probation Services Fund."
      (1)   All monies collected by the Probation Department of the Town Court
shall be transferred to the town's fiscal officer.
      (2)   Upon their receipt, the fiscal officer shall deposit these monies
into the fund set forth above.
   (B)   The Town Council shall appropriate money from the fund to the Town
Court:
      (1)   For its use in providing adult probation services; or
      (2)   For other purposes.
(Ord. 2001-G-01, passed 1-30-01)
§ 36.186 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   The monies deposited in the special fund may be used for all
reasonable and necessary expenditures incurred in providing probation services
for adult defendants adjudicated to probation in the Town Court, and thereafter
for other court services as may be allowed by statute.
   (B)   The Town Court is hereby required to use the special fund to the
extent and manner allowed by law.
   (C)   The authorization for the special fund shall expire when a subsequent
ordinance so provides, and any funds remaining in the fund shall be transferred
to the town's General Fund.
(Ord. 2001-G-01, passed 1-30-01)
NON-REVERTING FUND - VEHICLE TOWING FEES
§ 36.200 CREATED.
   A special non-reverting fund is hereby established for the purpose of
receiving and holding fees charged by the Clarksville Police Department for
towed vehicles, for training programs, for providing copies of law enforcement
recordings (as defined by the Indiana Access to Public Records Act), and for
providing fingerprinting services (for other than law enforcement purposes).
This fund shall be named “Clarksville Police Department Towed Vehicles Non-
Reverting Fund.” Hereafter, the Clerk-Treasurer shall not deposit money
received by the Clarksville Police Department as fees charged for towed
vehicles or for training programs or for providing law enforcement recordings
(as defined by the Indiana Access to Public Records Act) or for providing
fingerprinting services (other than law enforcement purposes) into the town’s
General Fund, but shall deposit those funds into the non-reverting fund.
(Ord. 2002-G-01, passed 1-8-02; Am. Ord. 2005-G-05, passed 7-26- 05; Am. Ord.
2014-G-05, passed 9-15-14; Am. Ord. 2016-G-1, passed 2-1-16; Am. Ord. 2017-G-
12, passed 11-7-17)
Cross-reference:
   For provisions regarding imposition of vehicle towing fees, see §
35.04.
§ 36.201 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   Moneys may be expended from this fund upon filing a proper claim in
issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer after appropriation by the Town
Council.
   (B)   The Clarksville Police Department may use funds in this non-reverting
fund that are derived from fees collected for the copying of a law enforcement
recording only to purchase cameras and other equipment for use in connection
with the law enforcement recording program, for training concerning law
enforcement recording, or to defray the expenses of storing, producing, and
copying law enforcement readings.
   (C)   The Clarksville Police Department may use the remaining funds from
this non-reverting fund for reasonable and necessary Police Department
expenditures for training, safety equipment and safety related purposes as
allowed by law.
   (D)   The Clarksville Town Council is hereby required to use the non-
reverting fund to the extent and manner provided by law.
   (E)   The authorization for the above non-reverting fund shall expire when a
subsequent ordinance so provides, and funds in the account shall then be
transferred to the town’s General Fund.
(Ord. 2002-G-01, passed 1-8-02; Am. Ord. 2004-G-06, passed 12-14- 04; Am. Ord.
2005-G-05, passed 7- 26-05; Am. Ord. 2014-G-05, passed 9-15-14; Am. Ord. 2016-
G-1, passed 2-1-16; Am. Ord. 2017-G-12, passed 11-7-17)
NON-REVERTING FUND - STATE ROAD 131
§ 36.215 CREATED.
   (A)   There is created a fund entitled the "Nonreverting Highway 131
Construction/ Maintenance Fund."
   (B)   The monies in the amount of $2,200,000 received from the State of
Indiana under the agreement regarding the transfer of responsibility for the
roadway which has been known as State Road 131 shall be deposited into the
Nonreverting Highway 131 Construction/Maintenance Fund .
(Ord. 2003-G-05, passed 4-29-03)
§ 36.216 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   The monies referred to in §
36.215(B) shall be disbursed from the fund without the necessity of obtaining
an appropriation through a proceeding before the Department of Local Government
Finance.
   (B)   Moneys may be expended from the fund only upon the filing of a proper
claim which follows the claim procedures required by the statutes of the State
of Indiana and town ordinances.
(Ord. 2003-G-05, passed 4-29-03)
MISCELLANEOUS FEES
§ 36.230 DISHONORED CHECK FEE.
   (A)   Any department of the town may charge a fee, together with protest
fees and any service fee or charge, which may not exceed the greater of $27.50
or 5% (but not more than $250) of the amount due, that may be charged by the
payee or holder, within ten days after the date of mailing by the payee or
holder of notice to the person that the check, draft, or order has not been
paid by the credit institution. Notice sent in the manner set forth in IC 26-2-
7-3 constitutes notice to the person that the check, draft, or order has not
been paid by the credit institution. The payee or holder of a check, draft, or
order that has been dishonored incurs no civil or criminal liability for
sending notice under this subsection.
   (B)   Further, the town may also pursue a civil action against the person
who caused the loss as a result of a violation of IC 35-42-3-3, 35-42-3-4, 35-
43 or 35-45-9, for the following:
      (1)   An amount not to exceed three times the actual damages of the
person suffering the loss.
      (2)   The costs of the action.
      (3)   A reasonable attorney's fee.
      (4)   Actual travel expenses that are not otherwise reimbursed under
divisions (1) through (3) and are incurred by the person suffering loss to:
         (a)   Have the person suffering loss or an employee or agent of that
person file papers and attend court proceedings related to the recovery of a
judgment under this chapter; or
         (b)   Provide witnesses to testify in court proceedings related to the
recovery of a judgment under this chapter.
      (5)   A reasonable amount to compensate the person suffering loss for
time used to:
         (a)   File papers and attend court proceedings related to the recovery
of a judgment under this chapter; or
         (b)   Travel to and from activities described in division (5)(a)
above.
      (6)   Actual direct and indirect expenses incurred by the person
suffering loss to compensate employees and agents for time used to:
         (a)   File papers and attend court proceedings related to the recovery
of a judgment under this chapter; or
         (b)   Travel to and from activities described in division (6)(a)
above.
      (7)   All other reasonable costs of collection.
   (C)   All of this is pursuant to IC 34-24-3-1.
(Ord. 2002-G-03, passed 2-12-02; Am. Ord. 2009-G-10, passed 8-17-09)
§ 36.231 PUBLIC RECORD COPYING FEE.
   (A)   Pursuant to IC 5-14-3-3, any person, firm or corporation directing a
request to any agency within the Town of Clarksville shall be charged $0.10 per
page for copies that are not color copies and $0.25 per page for color copies
for each page copied in fulfilling the request. This fee shall not include
electronic maps of the Planning Department. Any person, firm or corporation
directing a request to the Planning Department for an electronic map shall be
charged $1 for each copy of an 11 x 17 inch black and white map; $2 for each
copy of an 11 x 17 inch color map; and $3.33 per square foot for maps from the
large scale printer.
   (B)   A person, firm, or corporation requesting a copy of a law enforcement
recording (as defined by the Access to Public Records Act) shall be charged
$82.50 per recording.
   (C)   A person, firm, or corporation requesting the Clarksville Police
Department to fingerprint a person for other than law enforcement purposes
shall be charged a fee of $20 per fingerprinting service.
(Ord. 2007-G-02, passed 8-28-07; Am. Ord. 2008-G-02, passed 6-16- 08; Am. Ord.
2017-G-11, passed 11-7-17)
PARKS NON-REVERTING SECURITY/DAMAGE DEPOSIT FUND
§ 36.240 CREATED.
   (A)   There is hereby created a fund of the town entitled the "Parks Non-
reverting Security/Damage Deposit Fund."
   (B)   The monies received from persons proposing to rent the buildings or
facilities of the Parks and Recreation Department which require a security/
damage deposit shall be deposited into this Parks Non-reverting Security/Damage
Deposit Fund.
(Ord. 2005-G-01, passed 1-11-05)
§ 36.241 DISBURSEMENT OF FUND.
   (A)   Disbursements from this fund shall be made for the purposes of either
returning security/damage deposits to those persons entitled to refunds, or for
transferring funds to the Parks and Recreation GeneralFund of any security/
damage deposits made by persons who do not fulfill their obligations and who
therefore are not entitled to receive a refund of their deposits.
   (B)   Monies may be disbursed from the Parks Non-reverting Security/Damage
Deposit Fund without appropriation upon the filing of a proper claim which
follows the claim procedures required by the statutes of the State of Indiana
and the ordinances of the town.
(Ord. 2005-G-01, passed 1-11-05)
§ 36.242 EXPIRATION OF FUND AUTHORIZATION.
   The authorization for the non-reverting fund established by this subchapter
shall expire when security/damage deposit fees are no longer required for any
reason in connection with the rental of Parks Department buildings or
facilities or upon the adoption of a subsequent ordinance revoking the
provisions this subchapter, and any monies in the account which cannot be
refunded to the person who made the deposit shall be transferred into the
town's Parks and Recreation General Fund.
(Ord. 2005-G-01, passed 1-11-05)
RAINY DAY FUND
§ 36.250 CREATED.
   The Town Council for the Civil Town of Clarksville, Indiana, hereby
establishes the Town of Clarksville Rainy Day Fund.
(Ord. 2007-G-01, passed 2-13-07; Am. Ord. 2014-G-02, passed 5-19-14)
§ 36.251 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   The purpose for the Rainy Day Fund is to maintain funds which may be
used for the purposes set forth in state law.
   (B)   The sources for funding the Rainy Day Fund may include the following:
      (1)   IC 36-1-8-5;
      (2)   IC 6-3.5-1.1-21.1; and/or
      (3)   IC 6-3.5-6-17.3.
   (C)   The Rainy Day Fund is subject to the same appropriation process as
other funds which receive tax funds.
   (D)   In any fiscal year, the town may not transfer more than 10% of the
town’s annual budget for that fiscal year to the Rainy Day Fund.
   (E)   The town may only use the funding sources specified in IC 36-1-8-5.1
(b)(2)(A), or in this subchapter. The Town Council may adopt a subsequent
ordinance authorizing the use of another funding source.
   (F)   The Department of Local Government may not reduce the actual or
maximum permissible levy for the Town of Clarksville as a result of a balance
in the Rainy Day Fund.
(Ord. 2007-G-01, passed 2-13-07; Am. Ord. 2014-G-02, passed 5-19-14)
NON-REVERTING FUND - BROADWAY CORRIDOR
§ 36.255 CREATED.
   A non-reverting fund is hereby established for the purpose of receiving,
holding and dispersing monies contributed by builders/developers to assist in
the payment of necessary municipal improvements to the Broadway Corridor. The
fund shall be titled “Clarksville Broadway Corridor Improvement Fund.” The
Clarksville Clerk-Treasurer shall deposit monies received from the Broadway
Corridor builders/developers into this fund.
(Ord. 2007-G-03, passed 11-13-07)
§ 36.256 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   Monies from the Clarksville Broadway Corridor Improvement Fund may be
dispersed in payment after:
      (1)   The appropriation of funds by the Town Council;
      (2)   The filing of a proper claim; and
      (3)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (B)   Monies deposited into the Clarksville Broadway Corridor Improvement
Fund may be used for all reasonable and necessary expenditures in making the
municipal improvements to the Broadway Corridor.
   (C)   The Clarksville Redevelopment Commission is required to use the
Clarksville Broadway Corridor Improvement Fund to the extent and in a manner
allowed by law.
(Ord. 2007-G-03, passed 11-13-07)
§ 36.257 EXPIRATION OF FUND AUTHORIZATION.
   Authorization for the Clarksville Broadway Corridor Improvement Fund shall
expire when the Redevelopment Commission determines and notifies the Town
Council that all necessary municipal improvements have been completed or as a
subsequent ordinance provides. Any monies remaining in the Clarksville Broadway
Corridor Improvement Fund upon the completion of all necessary municipal
improvements shall be transferred to the Clarksville Redevelopment Commission
General Fund.
(Ord. 2007-G-03, passed 11-13-07)

Reverting Fund for Accumulated Leave Time". The Fund is established for the

INTERNAL SERVICE FUND
§ 36.275 TOWN VEHICLE REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby established an internal service fund designated as the
Town Vehicle Repair and Maintenance Fund.
   (B)   The Town Vehicle Repair and Maintenance Fund, which shall be used to
advance amounts invoiced by vendors of parts, suppliers, or materials for
repairs by the Street Department garage to town owned vehicles, shall be funded
by an initial transfer of unappropriated funds in the General Fund in the
amount of $5,000 and shall be subsequently funded by periodic transfers of
funds from the various departments that use the Street Department’s garage for
repairs and maintenance.
   (C)   When the Street Department receives an invoice from a vendor for
parts, supplies or materials for repair or maintenance to any town owned
vehicle, the Street Department shall forward the invoice to the Town Vehicle
Repair and Maintenance Fund for payment. Payments from the Town Vehicle Repair
and Maintenance Fund shall be made without appropriation. A copy of the invoice
shall be forwarded to the Department whose vehicle was repaired or maintained.
   (D)   Upon receipt of the invoice, the Clerk-Treasurer’s office shall
transfer a sufficient amount from the department whose vehicle was repaired or
maintained into the Town Vehicle Repair and Maintenance Fund at such times, in
such amounts, and charge the respective department funds and appropriations as
deemed necessary and proper by the Clerk-Treasurer, and these reimbursements
shall be granted pre-approved expenditure status.
   (E)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to require the implementation of any
additional procedures in connection with the administration of the Town Vehicle
Repair and Maintenance Fund as may be deemed necessary.
(Ord. 2012-G-02, passed 2-6-12)

ELECTRONIC MAP GENERATION FUND
§ 36.285 CREATED; PURPOSE.
   (A)   Purpose and authority.
      (1)   The town is providing electronic mapping;
      (2)   Pursuant to IC 5- 14-3-8(j), the town has passed an ordinance that
allows the town to charge a fee, uniform to all purchasers, for providing an
electronic map that is based upon the reasonable percentage of the direct cost
of maintaining, upgrading and enhancing the electronic map and for the direct
cost of supplying the electronic map in the form requested;
      (3)   Pursuant to IC 5- 14-3-8.5, the town must adopt an ordinance
establishing an electronic map generation fund;
      (4)   The town has determined that the fund shall be a non-reverting
fund; and
      (5)   Pursuant to IC 5- 14-3-8.5 the town desires to establish the
Electronic Map Generation Non-Reverting Fund (the Fund) pursuant to the
provisions contained herein.
   (B)   The Electronic Map Generation Non-Reverting Fund shall be and is
hereby established.
   (C)   The Planning Department hereby establishes in its operating budget a
fund designated as the Electronic Map Generation Non-Reverting Fund. Any
balance remaining at the end of the fiscal year shall be carried over in the
Fund for the following year and does not revert to the General Fund.
   (D)   Money for the Electronic Map Generation Non- Reverting Fund may be
received from fees collected under IC 5- 14-3-8(j).
(Ord. 2012-G-15, passed 11-19-12)
§ 36.286 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   Money in the Electronic Map Generation Non-Reverting Fund may be used
for the expenses incurred in carrying out the purposes of IC 5-14-3-8,
including:
      (1)   The cost of the maintenance, upgrading, and enhancement of the
electronic map; and
      (2)   The cost of the reimbursement of expenses incurred by the town in
supplying an electronic map in the form requested.
   (B)   Payments or uses of the Fund shall be made through claim procedure,
without necessity of appropriation by the Town Council in accordance with
applicable law.
(Ord. 2012-G-15, passed 11-19-12)

HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION NON-REVERTING FUND
§ 36.290 CREATED; PURPOSE.
   (A)   Purpose and authority.
      (1)   The Town Council has established the Historic Preservation
Commission pursuant to IC 36-7-11, to provide a means to promote the cultural,
economic, and general welfare of the public through the preservation and
protection of structures and areas of historic and cultural interest within the
town.
      (2)   The town has determined that there is a need to establish a non-
reverting fund for this historic preservation to be utilized by the Historic
Preservation Commission.
      (3)   The town desires to establish the Historic Preservation Commission
Non- Reverting Fund (the Fund) pursuant to the provisions contained herein.
   (B)   The Historic Preservation Commission Non-Reverting Fund shall be and
is hereby established.
   (C)   The Historic Preservation Commission hereby establishes in its
operating budget a fund designated as the Historic Preservation Fund. Any
balance remaining at the end of a fiscal year shall be carried over in the Fund
for the following year and does not revert to the General Fund.
   (D)   Money for the Historic Preservation Fund may be received from any
source, including appropriations by local, state, or federal governments, and
donations.
   (E)   The following shall be deposited in the Fund:
      (1)   Money received as payment for or settlement of obligations or
judgments established under IC 36-7-11.
      (2)   Money received from bonds posted.
      (3)   Money received in satisfaction of receivers’ notes or certificates
that were issued and were purchased with money from the Historic Preservation
Fund.
      (4)   Money received for payment or settlement of civil penalties or
fines.
      (5)   Money received from the collection of special assessments.
(Ord. 2012-G-17, passed 11-19-12)
Cross-reference:
   Historical Preservation Commission, see §§
33.80 through
33.98
§ 36.291 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   Money in the Historic Preservation Fund may be used for the expenses
incurred in carrying out the purposes of I.C. 36-7-11, including:
      (1)   The cost of an examination of the property by a registered
architect or registered engineer not employed by the department;
      (2)   The cost of surveys necessary to determine the location and
dimensions of real property;
      (3)   The cost of maintaining the property, restoring the property, and/
or demolition of the property;
      (4)   The cost of giving notice of orders, notice of statements of
rescission, notice of continued hearing, and notice of statements that public
bids;
      (5)   The bid price of work by a contractor; and
      (6)   Any costs deemed necessary by the Commission.
   (B)   Payments or uses of the Fund shall be made through claim procedure,
without necessity of appropriation by the Town Council in accordance with
applicable law.
(Ord. 2012-G-17, passed 11-19-12)
INVESTMENT OF PUBLIC FUNDS
§ 36.300 INVESTMENT OF PUBLIC FUNDS.
   Pursuant to I.C. 5-13-9-5.7, the Town Council authorizes the Clerk-Treasurer
(the "investing officer") of the town to make investments having a stated final
maturity that is more than two years, but not more than five years after the
date of purchase under the following circumstances:
   (A)   The fiscal body of the town shall first adopt an investment policy
authorizing the investment of public funds of the town for more than two years
and not more than five years in accordance with I.C. 5-13-9-5.7(a) and (b).
   (B)   This section and the power to make an investment having a stated final
maturity that is more than two years, but not more than five years after the
date of purchase expire on the date on which the investment policy expires,
which may not exceed four years.
   (C)   At the time an investment of public funds of the town is made having a
stated final maturity that is more than two years, but not more than five
years, the total of such investments of the town may not exceed 25% of the
total portfolio of public funds invested by the town, including balances in
transaction accounts.
   (D)   An investing officer may contract with a federally regulated
investment advisor or other institutional money manager to make such
investments.
(Ord. 2013-G-05, passed 8-5-13)
PARKS NON-REVERTING FUND/SALE OR USE OF GIFT CARDS
§ 36.305 CREATED.
   A special non-reverting operation fund is hereby established for the purpose
of receiving and holding money received by the Parks Department from the
purchase or use of gift cards. This fund shall be entitled “Clarksville Parks
and Recreation Non-Reverting Fund/Gift Cards” and the moneys may be expended
from this fund only upon the filing of a proper claim in issuance of a warrant
by the Park Board. Hereafter the Clerk-Treasurer shall not deposit into the
Park Department’s General Fund, moneys received by the Parks and Recreation
Department from the sale or use of gift cards, but shall deposit those funds
into said non- reverting fund.
(Ord. 2016-G-03, passed 3-21-16)
§ 36.306 USE OF FUNDS.
   That the moneys deposited in the special non-reverting operating fund may be
used to pay for Parks and Recreation Department activities, programs, trips,
user fees and classes by the holders of the gift cards.
(Ord. 2016-G-03, passed 3-21-16)
SPECIAL LOIT DISTRIBUTION FUND
§ 36.310 ESTABLISHMENT AND DISPOSITION.
   (A)   A special LOIT Distribution Fund is hereby created to receive money
from the special distribution of LOIT funds.
   (B)   That the moneys deposited in the special LOIT may be used as directed
in Senate Enrolled Act 67 of the 2016 Legislative session as follows:
      (1)   Local income tax distributions. Provides for a supplemental
distribution of local income taxes when the balance in a county’s local income
tax trust account exceeds 15% (rather than 50% under current law) of the
certified distributions to be made to the county;
      (2)   Specifies the accounting, allocation method, and distribution
requirements for supplemental distributions;
      (3)   Requires before May 2016 a one time special allocation of the
balance in a county’s trust account as of December 31, 2014;
      (4)   Provides that a taxing unit’s allocation amount is to be determined
in the same manner as a supplemental distribution would have generally been
determined under the former income taxes;
      (5)   Requires a special distribution of the allocation amount;
      (6)   Provides that at least 75% of the distributions made to a county,
city, or town must be:
         (a)   Used exclusively for local road construction, maintenance, or
repair, or a capital projects for aviation, including capital projects of an
airport authority; or
         (b)   Deposited in a rainy day fund and later used for those purposes;
      (7)   Provides that any remaining distribution to a county, city, or town
may be used for any purposes of the county, city, or town; and
      (8)   Requires the allocation amount for other taxing units to be
deposited in the taxing unit’s rainy day fund.
(Ord. 2016-G-05, passed 6-6-16)

CLARKSVILLE CLARKFEST NON-REVERTING FUND
§ 36.325 CREATED.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled Clarksville
ClarkFest Non-Reverting Fund is established for the purpose of receiving,
holding and dispersing monies that have been received by the ClarkFest
Committee. Hereafter the Clerk-Treasurer shall not deposit into the town's
General Fund or other funds any moneys received for ClarkFest but shall deposit
those funds into said non-reverting fund.
   (B)   ClarkFest committee may use funds from the Clarksville ClarkFest Non-
Reverting Fund for reasonable and necessary expenditures as allowed by law.
Monies from the Fund may be dispersed without appropriation in payment after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim by the chairman of the ClarkFest
committee; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (C)   Claims under this section may be treated as pre- approved claims
pursuant to 1C 36-5-4-12.
   (D)   Authorization for the Fund shall expire when the ClarkFest Committee
notifies the Town Council that the purposes of the Fund no longer exist or a
subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds remaining in the account shall
be transferred to the Fire General Fund.
(Ord. 2018-G-06, passed 7-17-18)
CLARKSVILLE FIRE NON-REVERTING F UND FOR MONIES COLLECTED FOR FALSE FIRE ALARMS
§ 36.330 CREATED.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled Clarksville Fire
Non-Reverting Fund for Monies Collected for False Fire Alarms. The Fund is
established for the purpose of receiving, holding and dispersing monies that
have been received by the Fire Department from responding to false fire alarms
under Ordinance No. 2018-G-07. Hereafter the Clerk- Treasurer shall not deposit
into the Fire Department's General Fund, moneys received for responding to
false fire alarms, but shall deposit those funds into said Non-Reverting Fund.
   (B)   Following an inventory and accounting of this Fund, the Fire
Department may use funds from the Clarksville Fire Non-Reverting Fund for
Monies Collected for False Fire Alarms for reasonable and necessary Fire
Department expenditures for fire prevention education, inspections, and to
purchase educational materials for firefighters as allowed by law. Monies from
the fire prevention education, inspections, and to purchase educational
materials for firefighters may be dispersed without appropriation in payment
after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (C)   Claims under this section may be treated as pre- approved claims
pursuant to IC 36-5-4-12.
   (D)   Authorization for the fund shall expire when the Fire Department
notifies the Town Council that the purposes of the Fund no longer exist or a
subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds remaining in the account shall
be transferred to the Fire General Fund.
(Ord. 2018-G-08, passed 7-17-18)

CLARKSVILLE PARKS DEPARTMENT FACILITIES NON-REVERTING FUND
§ 36.360 CREATED.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled “Clarksville Parks
Department Facilities Non-Reverting Fund” for the purpose of receiving, holding
and dispersing monies that have been received by the Clarksville Parks and
Recreation Department for sales of food and beverages and facility rentals at
Wooded View Golf Course and the Clarksville Little League Fields, including
applicable sales taxes collected. Revenues will be deposited as received by the
Clerk Treasurer only into the “Clarksville Parks Department Facilities Non-
Reverting Fund”, and funds exceeding operating costs may be transferred to the
Parks Department General Fund only at the request of the Parks Department
Superintendent.
   (B)   The Parks Department may use funds from the Clarksville Parks
Department Facilities Non-Reverting Fund for reasonable and necessary
expenditures for licensing, supplies, food and beverage, and other expenses
relating to operating, maintaining, and improving the areas contained by
Lapping Park and Gateway Park. Monies from the Clarksville Parks Department
Facilities Non-Reverting Fund may be dispersed without appropriation in payment
after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim by the Director of the Parks
Department; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (C)   Claims under this subchapter may be treated as preapproved claims
pursuant to IC 36-5-4-12.
   (D)   Authorization for the fund shall expire when the Clarksville Parks and
Recreation Department notifies the Town Council that the purposes of the fund
no longer exist or a subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds remaining
in the account shall be transferred to the Parks Department General Fund.
(Ord. 2021-G-01, passed 1-5-21; Am. Ord. 2022-G-18, passed 12-20-22)
CLARKSVILLE ANIMAL CONTROL  NON-REVERTING FUND
§ 36.365 CREATED.
   (A)   A non-reverting fund is hereby established titled "Clarksville Animal
Control Non-Reverting Fund" for the purpose of receiving, holding and
dispersing fees that have been received pursuant to the Animal Control
Ordinance. Hereafter the Clerk-Treasurer shall not deposit into the General
Fund or other funds any fees received pursuant to the Animal Control Ordinance
but shall deposit those funds into said non-reverting fund.
   (B)   The funds to be deposited into the Clarksville Animal Control Non-
Reverting Fund shall only include fees collected pursuant to the Animal Control
Ordinance and not fines imposed and collected pursuant to the ordinance.
   (C)   The funds from the Clarksville Animal Control Non-Reverting Fund may
be used for reasonable and necessary expenditures for supplies, equipment, and/
or vehicles and other expenses for enforcement of the Animal Control Ordinance.
Monies from the Clarksville Animal Control Non-Reverting Fund may be dispersed
without appropriation in payment after:
      (1)   The filing of a proper claim by the Director of the Public Works
Department; and
      (2)   The issuance of a warrant by the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (D)   The provisions of this subchapter shall apply to
Chapter 91 as enacted and as may be subsequently amended or replaced.
   (E)   Claims under this subchapter may be treated as preapproved claims
pursuant to IC 36-5-4-12.
   (F)   Authorization for the fund shall expire when the Director of the
Public Works Department notifies the Town Council that the purposes of the fund
no longer exist or a subsequent ordinance so provides and any funds remaining
in the account shall be transferred to the Town General Fund.
(Ord. 2021-G-02, passed 1-19-21)
Cross-reference:
   Animals, see
Chapter 91
